cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S.N. Company.
div.p: For rates, dates of sailing, and further particulars
See Notice on Page 2.

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about January 2.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Shropshire 5,785 tons, leaves about January 6.
Special reduced fares to government officials.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Fitted wtih Refrigerators, Electric Light, Electric fans, and all recent improvements.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG, weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from BORDEAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBURHG. Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special facilities for conveyances of cotton, etc. from Alexndria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns. For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.
The following are EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. "Tinos" January 5 from Hamburg.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: The Steamers of this Line leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for ALGIERS and LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
SALOON FARE £12. Special Summer season rates £12. Port Said to Marseilles £7.
S.S. MARTARAN, will leave PORT SAID about December 23 for London, Liverpool, and Glasgow.
S.S. TENASEERIm, sailing from PORT SAID about the January 4 for Devonport.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 13 days.
The Saloon accommodation is ... and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Light, and have all the latest improvements. For further information apply to the Company's Agents.
WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT & EXPLORATION COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: KHARTOUM: CAIRO Office, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.
SOLE AGENTS FOR Dudbridges Oil Engines from 1 to 35 B.H.P. as supplied to Sudan Government Seamless Steel Boat Co., Ltd., etc., etc. 31-10-906

div.head: GELLATLY, HANKEY & CO.
div.p: SHIPOWNERS OF LONDON.
Branches at Port Sudan, Suakin & Jeddah
Merchandise, furniture, baggage and personal effects forwarded, and insurances effected to all parts of the world.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

First class passengers steamers. Sailing fortnightly from Suez.

CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d'Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.

Branches: London (22 Fenchurch Street, corner of Rood Lane), Alexandria, Cairo, Khartoum, Volo, Patras, Syra, Calamata, Candia, Canea, Rethymo, Smyrna, Salonica, Cavalla.. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 4 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 20 to P.T. 20,000. 19-6-907

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,500,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah, Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street). La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd
div.p: Weekly Mail Steamers from ALEXANDRIA to BRINDISI, TRIESTE (VENTOR). leave Saturdays at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in connection with the morning Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. A Train de Luxe leaves the same evening, 6:35 p.m. for Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende, and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5:12 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Mail Steamers
leaves Alexandria to Brindisi and Trieste every Thursday at 4 p.m.
Syria-Caramania Cyprus Service

weekly Mail Steamers leave Alexandria every Sunday 3 p.m. for Ports Said, Jaffa, Caifa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Alexandretta, Mersins, Larnaos, and Limassol. N.B. During the present Quarantine restirctions boats leave Alexandria Sundays 2 p.m. proceed from Port Said to Beyront directly, thence to Jaffa, Aaifa, Tripoli, etc.
For information apply to the Co's Agencies: Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Cairo, Helouan, Port Sudan, Khartum, Messrs. THOS COOK & Son Ltd etc

The Marseilles London Steamers sail after the arrival of the 11 a.m train from Cairo on Tuesdays.

div.head: Sudan Express Mail Service
div.p: Three Days to Khartoum
By KHEDIVIAL MAIL EXPRESS 8.8. "PRINCE ABBAS" and "EL KAHIRA" and SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS 'Trains de Luxe."

Departures from SUEZ DOCKS every WEDNES. DAY. 5 p.m. after arrival of 11 a.m. Train from Cairo, with Through Carriages to alongside steamer. Special Sudan Government Train de Luxe with Sleeping and Dining Cars, awaits steamer's arrival at ORT SUDAN, FRIDAY EVENINGS, arriving KHARTOUM 8 p.m. SATURDAYS.

Returning from KHARTOUM, the Special Train leaves TUESDAYS 9.15 p.m. arriving alongside steamer at PORT SUDAN WEDNESDAY EVEN INGS. Steamer is timed to reach SUEZ SATUR. DAYS, to connect with 6.40 p.m, train to Cairo

Further particulars may be obtained from any of KHEDIVIAL MAIL LEINE'S Agencies or from Principal Tourist Agencies by whom Circular Tickets are iasued to Khartoum by the, Nile, returning b , Red Sea Express Service or Vice-Versa.

Editor and Manager - - R. SHELLING
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, JANUARY, 3, 1908.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN OFFICIALS.
div.p: Some interesting criticisms are passed on English officials in Egypt by the correspond. ent of the "Daily Telegraph” in Cairo, who sends the following article on the subject to the newspaper.
We have dealt with the subject in another column of to days issue.

It is impossible to live long in this country without becoming convinced that many of the reforms, in particular those of a mental or moral nature, are being wrongly applied. Instead of attempting to convince the Egyptian why some rule of conduct or mode of thought is inferior to, and more usefal than, those he at present follows, he is merely told he is wrong, and that he must alter--a course which merely confirms the Egyptian in his error, if error it be, and breeds a mistrust of reform and of the object of those who urge it.

No effort whatever is made by the younger Government officials to understand the people whom they are here to govern; they do not attempt to find out what circamstances and what ideals and inner feelings have conduced to forming the Egyptian's habit of thought and mode of life They do not pause to reflect that this has been reached after centuries of experience of religious, mental, and physical conditions of which the Englishman knows nothing. They do not seem to realise that in a philosophy thus arrived at there is much that is good and much that is more suitable to the native than that which has been the outcome of Westeru experience. The young official parti. cularly in the educational department, seems to have no idea of building on what he finds his great idea is to demolish. Hide-bound by this lack of experience of life and by the narrow, conventions of his University, he wishes to force the game outlook and the same ideals on a race totally unfitted for them by religion, training, tradition, and environment.

This is the attitude which has erected the barrier between the two races, a barrier which practically precludes all social intercourse; and which will, unless it is destroyed at once and for ever, become one of the most dangerous and effective weapons in the armoary of our political opponents. Set up in our arrogance, let us beware it is not demolished to our humiliation.

Another danger is the increasing frequency with which Egyptians are sent to study in England, dangerous because of the way they are treated on their return. While there they are treated in exactly the same manner as are all other members of the community among whom they are made much of, if the reverse they are shunned. But on the arrival of one of these Egyptians in his own country he finds he is treated in an entirely different manner, and in some cases even the very people who were his friends in England and his contemporaries "at the University draw away, and another is added to the enemies of the occupation, and, because of his education and his modern training, & more important one.

The Egyptian is often called ungrateful, and in many cases this is absolutely true. But is it not the manner of giving that is at fault ! It is against human nature to be unduly grateful for benefits that are flung to you.

Many of the reasons urged in defence of this racial barrier are undoubtedly true, chief among which are the different social position of women, the social conditions, and the ideas of right and wrong, the difference of which springs entirely from the difference in religion. Here, however, the young officials apt to forget that East is East and West is West, and imagines that East can be made into a sort of stucco imitation of the West ; he seldom attempts to discover from what these differences come, so that by & proper realisation of the sources from which they spring they may be, 'as far as possible, smoothed away. This latter course was the one followed by the earlier officials here, and is still to a very great extent by the higher ones. A less haughty and exclusive attitude must be adopted by the young gentleman who arrives here fresh from his University and finds himself suddenly placed in a position of considerable responsibility. Otherwise, the magnitude of our task here will be increased. The younger official has a very high ideal of duty, but he seems not to realise that human sympathy is an even more valuable asset in the equipment of those who have to govern, and that an attempt should be made to understand the outlook op life which others have.

It cannot be too strongly insisted on that this attitude of exclusiveness is one of the chief factors in the racial antagonism that is undoubtedly growing in Egypt. And it is the English who are most to blame, for he is a rigid adherent to small and unimportant conventions, whereas the East is lavish in its hospitality. How often is an advance made by the Egyptians in all good faith, and with all kindness treated as impertinence? Socially, the Mohamınecans are the most democratic People in the world, are not all Byual in the sight of Allah.

If the Egyptian is to absorb the good from our social and official system, and not only Western vices, we must help him to see their advantage by a closer intercourse, and not make them unpalatable in the giving. The barm done by the standers of the average young Englishman cannot be exaggerated; it to great extent counterbalances the benefits conferred by the labours and the genius of the great of our race.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From Our Own CORRESPONDENT.)
London, December 19th.

The Duke of Connaught on taking up his duties at Malta an Commander in Chief of the Mediterranean garrisons, will have practically the staff that he had whilst holding the appointment of Inspector General to the Forces He and the Duchess will embark for Valetta about the 2nd January, leaving Marseilles on that date

The new appointment will tend to throw Gibraltar more into the shade, as it will be overshadowed by supreme entrol from Malta, but virtually the appointment will not interfere with things in Egypt For a considerable time the Army Council was undecided as to whether Malta or Cairo should be made the Duke's headquarters, but eventually the island garrison was chosen as the most central point. How this will work in wartime is another question.

An exchange has been sanctioned between Captain the Honourable A.C. Murray, 2nd Battalion 5th Ghurka Rifles, Indian Army, and Captain J.M.V. Stewart, 2nd Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers. Captain Murray, who joined the Indian Staff Corps in 1899, and he holds the China medal for the Boxer campaign of 1900
Orders have been given that driver recruites for the Royal Field Artillery must be between 5 ft. 5 in. and 5 ft. 7 in. in height.
In the current issue of the Army List, Officers of the Militia, Yeomanry and Volunteers who have seen active service are so distinguished by crossed swords opposite their names.

It has been decided that from the commencement of the musketry training of the year 1908, the quantity of small arms ammunition to be expended by every trained cavalry and infantry soldier for practice and exercise under paragraph 1-5, Part 1, shall be limited to 250 rounds.

The new torpedo boat destroyer "Tartar" has just established a world's record in fast steaming. At her recent speed trials off Maplin, over the measured core she ran six consecutive trials at an average speed of 85.672 knots per hour, 35.363 knots per hour on the six hours' continuous steaming trial and on the measured mile she recorded a speed of 37 037 knots, or the equivalent of 44 miles per hour. Her builders are Messrs Thorneycroft, and the Admiralty stipulated only for 33 knots. The

Tartar," which is one of a flotilla of seven similar boats, measures 270 feet in length, with a beam of 26 feet, and a displacement of 795 tons. She is fitted with turbine driven engines of 14,500 h.p. supplied by oil fired water to be boilers. The armament consists of three 12 pounder quickfirers, and the usual torpedo equipment for the discharge of 18-inch torpedos, of which she will carry a senre, and the crew will consist of 60 of all ranks.
Next year's have maneuvers are to be held in the North Sen. Over 130 battleships, cruisers, and smaller ships will participate.

An idea of the naval strength concentrated in home waters may be gathered from the fact that between Christmas and the New Year some 80,000 men and marines of the Channel, Atlantic and Home Fleets will proceed on leave. The Channel Fleet has not been at home at this time of the year for a long period.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND RAMLEH RAILWAY COMPANY, LIMITED.
div.p: EXERCICE 1906-1907.
Le rapport suivant du Conseil d'Administration a été lu à l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire des Actionnaires du Lundi 80 Décembre 1907.

Messieurs, Nous avons l'honneur de vons présenter les comptes de The Alexandria and Ramleh Railways Company Limited, du 1er Detobre 1906 | au 30 Septembre 1907. Les résultats en sont très satisfaisants.

1:--ACTIF Premier Etablissement. — Ce compte s'élevait au 30 Septembre 1906 a P.T. 15.816.688.4 et au 30 Septembre 1907 à P.T. 76.664.582.2 soit une augmentation de P.T. 847.898.8 Cette augmentation provient : 1. De l'abaissementet du déplacement de notre voie pas quite dn prolongementdo Bonlevard de Ramleh depuis la rue Khartoum, jusqu'à la tranchée de Hat-elNar. 2. De la construction d'un garage à la gare d'Alexandrie pour l'établissement du service gpécial entre Alexandrie et Ibrahimieh. 3. De l'achèvement du remplacemont des vieux rails

double champignon par des rails Vignole et de la clôture de la voie. 4. De l'achat de quatre voitures motrices et de quatre voitures remorqnées, jugé indispensable par suite de l'augmentation du trafio. 5. De l'agrandissement des immeubles aux gares, de Sidi-Gaber et de Bacos, et divers travaux de construction complémentaires au dépôt de Moustapha Pacba. 6. De la construction de la ligne aérienne sur le prolongement du Boulevard de Ramleh et du prolongement de la ligne du Palais jusqu'au Victoria College en construction, à Siouf.
Magasin.-P.T. 1.443.748. 7. Ces chiffres représentent la valeur du matériel et des approvisionnements en magasi, suivant inventaire.
L. Steinschneider. - Compte achat Casino. P.T. 5.191.903. 9. Ce compte représente le solde du sur l'achat par lui fait do Casino San Stefano, capital et intérêts.
Société Aponymedes Tramways d'Alexandrie. - P.T. 2.300.014. 9 représentant les avances faites à cette Société en compte-courant.
Titres Compte Tiers -- P. T. 78.000 -- représentant la valeur nominale des titres qualificatifs des Administrateurs.
IL-PASSIF.
Emprunt obligations. - P. T. 1.699.000.Cé compte se trouve rédait cette année de | P.T. 117.000 par l'amortissement de 12 obligations au 31 Décembre 1906.

Créanciers divers P.T. 1.321.250,1. Ces chiffres sont représentés par les versements de l'Exploitation des Tramways de la Ville au 30 Septembre pour la somme de P.T. 1.807.812,6 et le solde par les créances de divers fournisseurs.
Conseil d'Administration. - Compte dépot P.T. 78.000. Coutre partie du compte "Titres compte tiers" à l'actif. COMPTE PROFITS ET PERTES

AU CREDIT Le solde reporté de l'Exercice précédent P. T. 28.060,2, Recettes générales P. T. 7.268 916,6, Intérêts, commissions et bénéfices divers P.T. 167.967,4 forment un total de P. T. 7.464,944,2.

. AU DEBIT Dépenses générales P. T. 4.179.634, 2. Le solde en bénéfice est donc de P.T. 3.285.310. D'après le contrat d'affermage intervenu entre notre Compagnie et la Société Anonyme des Tramways d'Alexandrie, le bénéfice Spécial qui vous revient sur l'exploitation du réseau de la Ville (Art. 3 du dit contrat) du 1er Janvier au 31 Décembre 1906 s'élève à la somme de P. T. 155.990,2. En ajoutant cette somme aux bénéfices précités, nong obtenons un solde total de bénéfice de P.T. 3.441.300,2, que nous vous proposons de répartir de la manière suivante : 1. Un dividende de 25% soit sb. 5 par action de Lstg. 1 nominale P.T. 2.681 250; 2. Au Fonds de Renouvellement P.T 500.000 ; 3. Gratification aux employés, P.T. 60,000; 4. Prévoyance pour accidents, trais judiciaires et risques en cours PT. 150.000 ; 5. Solde å reporter P. T. 50 050, 2; Total P. T. 3.441.300. 2.

Comme vous l'observerez dans la répartition des bénéfices, nons avons jugé utile de porter au Fonds de Renouvellement une somme de L.E. 5.000 au lieu de L. E. 4 000 oomme l'an dernier, et cela en considération de l'augmentation de matériel roulant pendant l'exercice. Nous avons en outre prélevé, sur les bénéfices unesomme de L.E. 500 en prévision de risques éventuels, d'accidents et de procès en cours. Nous sommes heureux de dire que pendant l'exercice que nous venons de clôturer, le trafic n'a cessé de se développer, donnant un résultat des plus satisfaisants. En effet, les recettes ont atteint le chiffre de P.T. 7.268.916, 6, contre P.T. 6.423.077, 3, soit une augmentation de P.T. 815.839, 3. Les dépenses ont été de P. T. 4.79.634. 2, tandis qne l'exercice passé elles étaient de P.T. 8.702.353, 5; elles n'ont donc augmenté que de P.T. 477.280. 7, laissant une augmentation des bénéfices d'Exploitation de PT. 368.558, 6. Le coefficient d'exploitation a été de 57,50 % contre 58,66 % l'année précédente.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head: Cheap Prepaid Advertisements
div.p: Under this heading advertisements are inserted at the following rates :—
The address is counted. The advertisement must appear on consecutive days for above rates to be obtained. 50% extra is charged for advertisements not appearing consecutively.

All such advertisements must be prepaid, and to this rule no exception whatever will be made. Letters in reply to advertisements will be posted to any address if a few stamps are sent by the advertiser to cover postage.

div.head: Winter Clothing
div.p: We have a full assortment of new and fashionable goods for the season.
Cloths for Suits Over Coats, etc.

Our stock in this department is the largest in Egypt. We show the newest and best cloths that can be bought and sell them at London prices. Our Cutters are the best in Egypt and we guarantee a perfect fit.
